title: The Road to Revolution
description: Rising Tensions. Britain imposes taxes and attempts to disarm colonists. The 'Powder Alarm' and similar raids convince Americans that an armed populace is the only check on tyranny.

title: The Continental Association
description: The First Charter of Union. The First Continental Congress creates a unified trade boycott against Britain, marking the first time the colonies acted as a single political entity.

title: The Revolutionary War
description: The War for Independence. Colonial militias and the Continental Army fight to overthrow British rule, cementing the distrust of standing armies.

title: Declaration of Independence
description: The Birth of the Nation. Congress unanimously adopts the Declaration, asserting the natural right of the people to alter or abolish destructive governments.

title: Articles of Confederation
description: The First Republic. Maryland finally ratifies the Articles, formally establishing a 'firm league of friendship' where states retained sovereignty and control over their militias.

title: Treaty of Paris
description: Independence Recognized. Britain formally recognizes American sovereignty and cedes territory east of the Mississippi. The war officially ends.

title: Shays' Rebellion
description: Armed uprising in Massachusetts. Revolutionary War veterans seize courthouses to stop debt hearings, proving the inability of the Confederation to maintain order.

title: The Constitutional Convention
description: The Grand Experiment. Delegates meet in secret to forge a new government.

title: Signing of the Constitution
description: The Convention concludes. 39 delegates sign the Constitution. The document is forwarded to the Confederation Congress.

title: The Ratification Debates
description: The Constitution goes to the states. A fierce battle erupts between Federalists and Anti-Federalists over the lack of listed rights.

title: The Federalist Papers
description: The Defense of the Constitution. Hamilton, Madison, and Jay begin publishing essays under the name 'Publius' to convince the public that a strong central government is necessary.

title: New Hampshire Ratifies
description: The Ninth Pillar. New Hampshire becomes the 9th state to ratify, satisfying Article VII. The Constitution is now officially the supreme law for the ratifying states.

title: The First Congress and Presidency of George Washington
description: The new government convenes. Madison fulfills his promise and leads the House in drafting the Bill of Rights. Washington inaugurated April 30th, 1789 and sets the precedents for the new republic, overseeing the ratification of the Bill of Rights and using the militia powers to enforce federal sovereignty.

title: Ratifying the Bill of Rights
description: Virginia becomes the 11th state to ratify, cementing the Bill of Rights—and the Second Amendment—into the Constitution.
